clinical_study.brief_title: Cold Snare Versus Double Biopsy Polypectomy Technique for Removal of Diminutive Colorectal Polyps
clinical_study.official_title: Cold Snare Versus Double Biopsy Polypectomy Technique for Removal of Diminutive Colorectal Polyps: a Prospective Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Most of colorectal polyps founded during colonoscopy are diminutive polyps less than 6 mm. However, complete removal of diminutive polyps is required to prevent tumor recurrence and development of potential interval cancers. Currently, a variety of polypectomy techniques such as hot snare, cold snare, and cold forceps polypectomy are frequently used for the removal of diminutive colorectal polyps. In regard to the completeness of polypectomy, there are few data comparing cold snare polypectomy with cold forceps biopsy technique for removal of diminutive (1-5 mm) colorectal polyps. The aim of this study is to compare cold snare polypectomy with cold forceps polypectomy using double biopsy technique for removal of diminutive colorectal polyps.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time taken for polypectomy (complete visual eradication of each polyp)
secondary_outcome.description: time from polyp resection to tissue retrieval

secondary_outcome.measure: Successful tissue retrieval rate of removed tissues

secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events include postpolypectomy bleeding and others (polypectomy syndrome or perforation).

intervention.intervention_name: removal of eligible polyps using cold snare polypectomy technique
intervention.description: Snare polypectomy using a mini (10 mm open diameter) size electrosurgical snare without application of electrocautery

intervention.intervention_name: removal of eligible polyps using double biopsy technique
intervention.description: Cold forceps polypectomy using a standard- capacity forceps with double biopsy technique (two bites per one forceps pass)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients over the age of 20
- Informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient undergoing antiplatelets (aspirin, clopidogrel and others) or anticoagulant therapy
- Known existing bleeding tendency (thrombocytopenia or prolonged INR)
- Inflammatory bowel diseases (Crohn's disease, or ulcerative colitis)
- ASA class III or more
- Pregnancy
- Any condition which, in the opinion of the Investigator, places the patient at unacceptable risk if he/she were to participate in the study
